Ref_Code: Speed <- cars$speed\nDistance <- cars$dist\nplot(Speed, Distance, panel.first = grid(8, 8), pch = 0, cex = 1.2, col = "blue")
Gen_Code:
# run_visible
df <- data.frame(cars)
data_summary(df)

# make_plot
png(filename)
df <- data.frame(cars)
plot(df$speed, df$dist, xlab = "Speed", ylab = "Distance", pch = 22, bg = 'blue', cex = 1.5)
grid(nx = 8, ny = 8)
dev.off()

Prompt: For the adult male passengers on the Titanic, make barplots of survivors and non-survivors subdivided by class
Ref_Code:
d.Titanic <- as.data.frame(Titanic)
barplot(Freq ~ Class + Survived, data = d.Titanic,
        subset = Age == "Adult" & Sex == "Male",
        main = "barplot(Freq ~ Class + Survived, *)", ylab = "# {passengers}", legend.text = TRUE)
Gen_Code:
png(filename)
# Load the Titanic dataset from an appropriate source
url <- "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/datasciencedojo/datasets/master/titanic.csv"
df <- read.csv(url)

# Filter for adult male passengers
adult_men <- df[df$Sex == "male" & df$Age >= 18, ]

# Create a table of survivors by class
survivors <- table(adult_men$Survived, adult_men$Pclass)

# Create barplot for survivors
barplot(survivors, main = "Survivors of Titanic Among Adult Male Passengers by Class",
        xlab = "Passenger Class",
        ylab = "Number of Passengers",
        col = c("lightblue", "salmon"),
        legend = rownames(survivors),
        beside = TRUE)

dev.off()
Note: Use adult males from Titanic dataset. Use barplot to show numbers of passenger in terms of survival (x axis) and class (stacking in bars - 1,2,3,Crew).

Prompt: For tooth growth of guinea pigs, make side-by-side box plots of tooth length for ascorbic acid and orange juice at different vitamin C doses. Color the bars ascorbic acid - yellow and orange juice - orange
Ref_Code:
boxplot(len ~ dose, data = ToothGrowth,
        boxwex = 0.25, at = 1:3 - 0.2,
        subset = supp == "VC", col = "yellow",
        main = "Guinea Pigs' Tooth Growth",
        xlab = "Vitamin C dose mg",
        ylab = "tooth length",
        xlim = c(0.5, 3.5), ylim = c(0, 35), yaxs = "i")
boxplot(len ~ dose, data = ToothGrowth, add = TRUE,
        boxwex = 0.25, at = 1:3 + 0.2,
        subset = supp == "OJ", col = "orange")
legend(2, 9, c("Ascorbic acid", "Orange juice"),
       fill = c("yellow", "orange"))
Gen_Code:
png(filename)

df <- ToothGrowth

df$dose <- as.factor(df$dose)

boxplot(len ~ supp * dose, data = df,
        col = c("yellow", "orange"),
        xlab = "Dose of Vitamin C",
        ylab = "Tooth Length",
        main = "Tooth Length by Supplement and Dose",
        legend.text = c("Ascorbic Acid", "Orange Juice"),
        beside = TRUE)

dev.off()
Note: Correct swapped colors for orange juice and vitamin C

Prompt: For tooth growth of guinea pigs, make side-by-side box plots of tooth length for ascorbic acid and orange juice at different vitamin C doses. Color the bars ascorbic acid - yellow and orange juice - orange
Ref_Code:

        boxwex = 0.5, col = c("orange", "yellow"),
        main = "Guinea Pigs' Tooth Growth",
        xlab = "Vitamin C dose mg", ylab = "tooth length",
        sep = ":", lex.order = TRUE, ylim = c(0, 35), yaxs = "i")

png(filename)
set.seed(123)

# Load the ToothGrowth dataset

data(ToothGrowth)

# Create a color vector for the boxplots

# Create a boxplot

        col = colors, 
        main = "Tooth Length by Supplement and Dose",
        xlab = "Dose and Supplement",
        ylab = "Tooth Length")

dev.off()
Note: Correct swapped colors for orange juice and vitamin C

Prompt: You have the following data for NASA space shuttle o-ring failures where 1 means 'no' and 2 means 'yes': fail <- c(2, 2, 2, 2, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 2, 1, 2, 1, 1, 1, 1, 2, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1) temperature <- c(53, 57, 58, 63, 66, 67, 67, 67, 68, 69, 70, 70, 70, 70, 72, 73, 75, 75, 76, 76, 78, 79, 81) Make a conditional density plot of o-ring failures given temperature
Ref_Code:
## NASA space shuttle o-ring failures
fail <- factor(c(2, 2, 2, 2, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 2, 1, 2, 1, 1, 1,
                 1, 2, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1),
               levels = 1:2, labels = c("no", "yes"))
temperature <- c(53, 57, 58, 63, 66, 67, 67, 67, 68, 69, 70, 70,
                 70, 70, 72, 73, 75, 75, 76, 76, 78, 79, 81)

## CD plot
cdplot(fail ~ temperature)
Gen_Code:
fail <- c(2, 2, 2, 2, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 2, 1, 2, 1, 1, 1, 1, 2, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1)
temperature <- c(53, 57, 58, 63, 66, 67, 67, 67, 68, 69, 70, 70, 70, 70, 72, 73, 75, 75, 76, 76, 78, 79, 81)

library(ggplot2)

data <- data.frame(fail, temperature)

# Convert 'fail' to a factor
data$fail <- factor(data$fail, levels = c(1, 2), labels = c('No', 'Yes'))

# Create a conditional density plot
ggplot(data, aes(x = temperature, fill = fail)) + 
  geom_density(alpha = 0.5) + 
  labs(title = "Conditional Density Plot of O-Ring Failures Given Temperature", x = "Temperature", y = "Density") + 
  theme_minimal()
Note: Incorrect tool call; No plot made: "error": "cannot coerce type 'object' to vector of type 'character'"

Prompt: You have the following data for NASA space shuttle o-ring failures where 1 means 'no' and 2 means 'yes': fail <- c(2, 2, 2, 2, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 2, 1, 2, 1, 1, 1, 1, 2, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1) temperature <- c(53, 57, 58, 63, 66, 67, 67, 67, 68, 69, 70, 70, 70, 70, 72, 73, 75, 75, 76, 76, 78, 79, 81) Plot a red line showing cumulative conditional density of o-ring failures given temperature. Overlay points for failure/no failure observations plotted at probability = 1 or 0.
Ref_Code:
## NASA space shuttle o-ring failures
fail <- factor(c(2, 2, 2, 2, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 2, 1, 2, 1, 1, 1,
                 1, 2, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1),
               levels = 1:2, labels = c("no", "yes"))
temperature <- c(53, 57, 58, 63, 66, 67, 67, 67, 68, 69, 70, 70,
                 70, 70, 72, 73, 75, 75, 76, 76, 78, 79, 81)

## scatter plot with conditional density
cdens <- cdplot(fail ~ temperature, plot = FALSE)
plot(I(as.numeric(fail) - 1) ~ jitter(temperature, factor = 2),
     xlab = "Temperature", ylab = "Conditional failure probability")
lines(53:81, 1 - cdens[[1]](53:81), col = 2)
Gen_Code:
fail <- c(2, 2, 2, 2, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 2, 1, 2, 1, 1, 1, 1, 2, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1)
temperature <- c(53, 57, 58, 63, 66, 67, 67, 67, 68, 69, 70, 70, 70, 70, 72, 73, 75, 75, 76, 76, 78, 79, 81)

# Define failure as a binary variable
failure <- ifelse(fail == 2, 1, 0)

# Calculate cumulative density of failures
cum_density <- cumsum(failure) / seq_along(failure)

# Set up the plot
png(filename)
plot(temperature, cum_density, type = "l", col = "red", lwd = 2,
     xlab = "Temperature (F)", ylab = "Cumulative Conditional Density of Failures",
     main = "Cumulative Conditional Density of O-Ring Failures vs. Temperature")

# Overlay points for failure/no failure
points(temperature, failure, pch = 19, col = ifelse(failure == 1, "red", "blue"))

# Add a horizontal line for reference
abline(h = 0, col = "grey")
abline(h = 1, col = "grey")
dev.off()"
Note: Use cdplot()

Prompt: For Tonga Trench Earthquakes plot latitude vs longitude conditioned on depth - use coplot() with quakes dataset
Ref_Code: coplot(lat ~ long | depth, data = quakes)
Gen_Code:
png(filename)
par(mfrow=c(1,2))
coplot(lat ~ long | depth, data = quakes, layout = c(1, 1), col = "blue", main = "Latitude vs Longitude conditioned on Depth")
dev.off()

Prompt: For Tonga Trench Earthquakes plot latitude vs longitude conditioned on four intervals of depth with an overlap of 0.1 - use coplot() with quakes dataset
Ref_Code: given.depth <- co.intervals(quakes$depth, number = 4, overlap = .1)\ncoplot(lat ~ long | depth, data = quakes, given.values = given.depth, rows = 1)
Gen_Code:
png(filename)
# Load the quakes dataset

data(quakes)

# Define depth intervals and colors
breaks <- seq(0, 700, by = 100)
colors <- c("blue", "green", "yellow", "red")

# Create coplot
coplot(lat ~ long | cut(depth, breaks = breaks), data = quakes, col = colors,
       number = 4, overlap = 0.1, xlab = "Longitude", ylab = "Latitude", 
       main = "Tonga Trench Earthquakes: Latitude vs Longitude by Depth Intervals")

dev.off()
Note: Use co.intervals to calculate intervals passed as given.values to coplot()

Prompt: Use warp breaks data and coplot(). Plot breaks vs index (row number) conditioned on wool and tension as crossed factors.
Ref_Code: ## given two factors\nIndex <- seq_len(nrow(warpbreaks)) # to get nicer default labels\ncoplot(breaks ~ Index | wool * tension, data = warpbreaks, show.given = 0:1)
Gen_Code:
png(filename)
# Load the warpbreaks dataset
data(warpbreaks)

# Generate the coplot
coplot(breaks ~ row.index | wool * tension, data = transform(warpbreaks, row.index = 1:nrow(warpbreaks)), panel = panel.smooth)
dev.off()

Prompt: A Topographic Map of Maunga Whau (single color)
Ref_Code:
rx <- range(x <- 10*1:nrow(volcano))
ry <- range(y <- 10*1:ncol(volcano))
ry <- ry + c(-1, 1) * (diff(rx) - diff(ry))/2
tcol <- terrain.colors(12)
par(pty = "s", bg = "lightcyan")
plot(x = 0, y = 0, type = "n", xlim = rx, ylim = ry, xlab = "", ylab = "")
u <- par("usr")
rect(u[1], u[3], u[2], u[4], col = tcol[8], border = "red")
contour(x, y, volcano, col = tcol[2], lty = "solid", add = TRUE,
        vfont = c("sans serif", "plain"))
title("A Topographic Map of Maunga Whau", font = 4)
abline(h = 200*0:4, v = 200*0:4, col = "lightgray", lty = 2, lwd = 0.1)

Prompt: iris data: Plot width vs length with symbols: s/v for Setosa/Versicolor, red/blue for petals/sepals, lowercase/uppercase for petals/sepals.

table(iris$Species) # is data.frame with 'Species' factor
iS <- iris$Species == "setosa"
iV <- iris$Species == "versicolor"
op <- par(bg = "bisque")
matplot(c(1, 8), c(0, 4.5), type =  "n", xlab = "Length", ylab = "Width",
        main = "Petal and Sepal Dimensions in Iris Blossoms")
matpoints(iris[iS,c(1,3)], iris[iS,c(2,4)], pch = "sS", col = c(2,4))
matpoints(iris[iV,c(1,3)], iris[iV,c(2,4)], pch = "vV", col = c(2,4))
legend(1, 4, c("    Setosa Petals", "    Setosa Sepals",
               "Versicolor Petals", "Versicolor Sepals"),
       pch = "sSvV", col = rep(c(2,4), 2))
Gen_Code:
png(filename)
# Load the iris dataset
 data(iris)

# Set up the plotting symbol: s for Setosa, v for Versicolor
 symbols <- ifelse(iris$Species == "setosa", "s", "v")

# Set up colors: red for petals, blue for sepals
 colors <- ifelse(iris$Petal.Length > 1.5, "red", "blue")

# Set up case: lowercase for petals, uppercase for sepals
 case <- ifelse(iris$Petal.Length > 1.5, "P", "S")

# Combine symbols, colors, and cases
 plot(iris$Sepal.Length, iris$Sepal.Width, pch=case, col=colors, cex=2,
      xlab="Sepal Length", ylab="Sepal Width", main="Sepal Width vs Length")

# Add legend
 legend("topright", legend=c("Setosa", "Versicolor"), pch=c("s", "v"), col=c("red", "blue"), title="Species")
 dev.off()
Note: Fix symbols and add petal data

Prompt: gait data: plot angle knee vs hip. different lines for each subject, label points with subject number
Ref_Code:
iS <- 1:3 # indices of subset
matplot(gait[, iS, 1], gait[, iS, 2], pch = "123", type = "b",
        col = rainbow(3, start = 0.8, end = 0.1),
        sub = paste(iS, dimnames(gait)[[2]][iS],
                    sep = "=", collapse= ",  "),
        xlab = "Hip angle", ylab = "Knee angle",
        main = "Hip and knee angle while walking")
Gen_Code:
# run_hidden
data(gait)
head(gait)
summary(gait)

# make_plot
png(filename)
plot(gait$hip, gait$knee, type='n', xlab='Hip Angle', ylab='Knee Angle', main='Knee vs Hip Angle by Subject')
text(gait$hip, gait$knee, labels=gait$subject, cex=0.7)
lines(gait$hip[gait$subject==1], gait$knee[gait$subject==1], col='red')
lines(gait$hip[gait$subject==2], gait$knee[gait$subject==2], col='blue')
lines(gait$hip[gait$subject==3], gait$knee[gait$subject==3], col='green')
lines(gait$hip[gait$subject==4], gait$knee[gait$subject==4], col='purple')
dev.off()
Note: No plot made: "error": "$ operator is invalid for atomic vectors"

Prompt: mosaic plot of survival on the Titanic contingent on sex (x) and age (y)
Ref_Code: mosaicplot(~ Sex + Age + Survived, data = Titanic, color = TRUE)
Gen_Code:
# run_visible
df <- as.data.frame(Titanic)
data_summary(df)

# make_plot
png(filename)
df <- as.data.frame(Titanic)
mosaicplot(~Sex + Age + Survived, data = df, main = "Mosaic Plot of Titanic Survival by Sex and Age", xlab = "Sex", ylab = "Age", color = TRUE)
dev.off()

Prompt: Make pairs plot of iris data, lower triangle only
Ref_Code: pairs(iris[1:4], main = "Anderson's Iris Data -- 3 species",\n      pch = 21, bg = c("red", "green3", "blue")[unclass(iris$Species)], upper.panel = NULL)
Gen_Code:
png(filename)
par(mfrow=c(2,2))
data(iris)

# Lower triangle
plot(iris[,1], iris[,2], main="Sepal.Length vs Sepal.Width", xlab="Sepal.Length", ylab="Sepal.Width")

plot(iris[,1], iris[,3], main="Sepal.Length vs Petal.Length", xlab="Sepal.Length", ylab="Petal.Length")

plot(iris[,1], iris[,4], main="Sepal.Length vs Petal.Width", xlab="Sepal.Length", ylab="Petal.Width")

plot(iris[,2], iris[,3], main="Sepal.Width vs Petal.Length", xlab="Sepal.Width", ylab="Petal.Length")

plot(iris[,2], iris[,4], main="Sepal.Width vs Petal.Width", xlab="Sepal.Width", ylab="Petal.Width")

plot(iris[,3], iris[,4], main="Petal.Length vs Petal.Width", xlab="Petal.Length", ylab="Petal.Width")

dev.off()
Note: Use pairs(..., upper.panel = NULL)

Prompt: Plot MDS of eurodist data with 1:1 aspect ratio for x and y axes. Show city names instead of points.
Ref_Code:
loc <- cmdscale(eurodist)
rx <- range(x <- loc[,1])
ry <- range(y <- -loc[,2])
plot(x, y, type = "n", asp = 1, xlab = "", ylab = "")
abline(h = pretty(rx, 10), v = pretty(ry, 10), col = "lightgray")
text(x, y, labels(eurodist), cex = 0.8)
Gen_Code:
png(filename)
library(MASS)
data(eurodist)
mds_result <- isoMDS(eurodist)
plot(mds_result$points, type = 'n', asp = 1, xlab = 'Coordinate 1', ylab = 'Coordinate 2', main = 'MDS of Eurodist Data')
text(mds_result$points, labels = rownames(eurodist))
dev.off()
Note: Labels are missing: use plot(x, y, ...) and text(x, y, ...)

Prompt: Use mean radius and mean perimeter from data. Calculate perimeter from 2*pi*mean radius, then calculate delta perimeter (calculated perimeter - mean perimeter). Plot delta perimeter (y) vs mean radius (x). Use symbols for diagnosis: solid red squares for M (malignant) and open black circles for B (benign). Apply 50% transparency to red and black colors.
Ref_Code:
df <- read.csv("data/breast-cancer.csv")
pch <- ifelse(df$diagnosis == "M", 15, 1)
col_B <- adjustcolor(1, alpha.f = 0.5)
col_M <- adjustcolor(2, alpha.f = 0.5)
col <- ifelse(df$diagnosis == "M", col_M, col_B)
p_calc <- df$radius_mean * 2 * pi
delta_p <- df$perimeter_mean - p_calc
plot(df$radius_mean, delta_p, pch = pch, col = col)
Gen_Code:
png(filename)
# Read the data from the CSV file

df <- read.csv("/tmp/uploads/breast-cancer.csv")

# Calculate the calculated perimeter from mean radius
calculated_perimeter <- 2 * pi * df$mean_radius

# Calculate delta perimeter

delta_perimeter <- calculated_perimeter - df$mean_perimeter

# Plot delta perimeter vs mean radius with different symbols for diagnosis
plot(df$mean_radius[df$diagnosis == 'M'], delta_perimeter[df$diagnosis == 'M'],
     col=rgb(1, 0, 0, 0.5), pch=22, bg='red',
     xlab="Mean Radius", ylab="Delta Perimeter",
     main="Delta Perimeter vs Mean Radius")
points(df$mean_radius[df$diagnosis == 'B'], delta_perimeter[df$diagnosis == 'B'],
       col=rgb(0, 0, 0, 0.5), pch=1)

legend("topright", legend=c("Malignant (M)", "Benign (B)"),
       pch=c(22, 1), pt.bg=c(rgb(1, 0, 0, 0.5), NA), col=c(rgb(1, 0, 0, 0.5), rgb(0, 0, 0, 0.5)))
dev.off()
Note: No plot made (error: 'x' and 'y' lengths differ). Use df$radius_mean and df$perimeter_mean.

Prompt: Generate three metrics for radius: 1. mean radius, 2. radius calculated from mean perimeter, 3. radius calculated from mean area (calculations using basic geometry formulas). Make a long data frame with diagnosis, metric (mean, perimeter, area), and radius values. Use factor interaction (?boxplot) to show radius grouped by diagnosis and metric.
Ref_Code:
df <- read.csv("data/breast-cancer.csv")
radius_peri <- df$perimeter_mean / 2 / pi
radius_area <- sqrt(df$area_mean / pi)
wide_df <- data.frame(diagnosis = df$diagnosis, radius_mean = df$radius_mean, radius_peri, radius_area)
long_df <- reshape(wide_df, direction = "long", varying = colnames(wide_df)[2:4], sep = "_", timevar = "metric")
boxplot(radius ~ metric:diagnosis, data = long_df)
Gen_Code:
## run_hidden
# Load necessary library
library(dplyr)

# Read the dataset
breast_cancer <- read.csv('breast-cancer.csv')

# Calculate mean radius
mean_radius <- mean(breast_cancer$radius)

# Calculate radius from mean perimeter (Perimeter = 2 * pi * radius) => radius = perimeter / (2 * pi)
mean_perimeter <- mean(breast_cancer$perimeter)
radius_from_perimeter <- mean_perimeter / (2 * pi)

# Calculate radius from mean area (Area = pi * radius^2) => radius = sqrt(area / pi)
mean_area <- mean(breast_cancer$area)
radius_from_area <- sqrt(mean_area / pi)

# Create a long data frame with diagnosis, metric, and radius values
radius_metrics <- data.frame(
  diagnosis = rep(breast_cancer$diagnosis, each = 3),
  metric = rep(c('mean', 'perimeter', 'area'), times = nrow(breast_cancer)),
  radius_values = c(
    rep(mean_radius, nrow(breast_cancer)),
    rep(radius_from_perimeter, nrow(breast_cancer)),
    rep(radius_from_area, nrow(breast_cancer))
  )
)

## run_visible
# Display the first few rows of the radius metrics data frame
head(radius_metrics)

# Check structure of the data frame
str(radius_metrics)

# Use boxplot to show radius grouped by diagnosis and metric
boxplot(radius_values ~ diagnosis + metric, data = radius_metrics, main = 'Radius by Diagnosis and Metric', xlab = 'Diagnosis and Metric', ylab = 'Radius', las = 2, cex.axis = 0.75)
Note: No plot made; use make_plot
